headline.main-hed: Poroshenko: Ukraine May Declare Brief Unilateral Cease-Fire

alt-summary-body.p: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko on Wednesday said government forces may declare a temporary unilateral cease-fire in the east in the coming days, laying out details of a plan discussed the day before with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin.

list-item.link: Video: Ukraine Cease-Fire Plan Laid Out

headline.main-hed: Poroshenko: Ukraine May Declare Temporary Unilateral Cease-Fire
headline.deck: Ukrainian President Lays Out Details of Plan Discussed with Vladimir Putin

article-body.byline: By James Marson and Lukas I. Alpert

media.media-caption: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko detailed a "peace plan" aimed at ending an uprising in the country's east that he discussed in a phone call with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin. James Marson reports. Photo: EPA

article-body.p: MOSCOW—Ukraine's President Petro Poroshenko said that government forces could declare a temporary, unilateral cease-fire in the country's rebellious east soon, an announcement that followed a discussion with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin.
Mr. Poroshenko, who took office early this month, has repeatedly promoted a peace plan even as he has stepped up a military offensive against pro-Russia rebels in two regions bordering Russia.

His proposal would briefly stop that operation to give the insurgents a chance to disarm. But he has said no deal would be implemented until Ukraine has regained full control of its border with Russia.
Ukrainian and U.S. officials say Russia has been sending irregular fighters and heavy weaponry across the border in recent weeks—a charge that Moscow denies.

highlight.link: Parts of Eastern Ukraine Gripped in 'Reign of Fear', Says U.N. Official
Pro-Russia Militia Seeks Help from Moscow
Poroshenko Calls for New Central Bank Chief

article-body.p: Though Russia expressed support for a cease-fire, there was no indication that the rebels would agree to give up their weapons.

Mr. Poroshenko discussed the cease-fire plan with Mr. Putin by phone late Tuesday. Mr. Putin's spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, said talks between Kiev and the rebels should immediately follow a cessation of fighting.
"Russia is most interested in a cease-fire and a peace process," he said in a telephone interview.

On Wednesday, Mr. Poroshenko said: "The plan will start with my order on a unilateral cease-fire." He said it would be "pretty short," and "we expect that disarmament of military groups and restoration of order will take place right after it."
"A key element of this plan is the shutdown of the border. There are huge risks that criminals will take advantage of the cease-fire," he said.
Mr. Poroshenko didn't elaborate on the the timing, but the acting defense minister later said the cease-fire would be declared in days.

Mr. Poroshenko said the government would propose an amnesty for rebels who lay down their weapons and hadn't committed grave crimes, and would open a corridor for what he called "mercenaries" to leave Ukraine without their weapons.

media.media-caption: President Petro Poroshenko, center, speaking Wednesday at the National University of Defense in Kiev, in a photo provided by his office.

article-body.p: Asked whether Russia would use its sway with the rebels to get them to stop shooting, Mr. Peskov said that Moscow's influence "shouldn't be overestimated."
Rebel leader Denis Pushilin told the Kremlin-run news channel RT that he didn't believe Mr. Poroshenko was being genuine, and called the peace plan a "mockery."

Mr. Poroshenko, a pro-Western billionaire chocolate baron who scored a decisive electoral victory on May 25, has so far been viewed as a unifying figure with few ties to the government that was overthrown in February. He has tried to capitalize on that broad support to stabilize the country, but protracted fighting could bring the honeymoon to an end.

The United Nations' Human Rights Monitoring Mission said in a report that at least 367 people had been killed in the conflict between May 7 and June 7, although it wasn't clear if that included military victims.
The Ukrainian Defense Ministry said that as of Wednesday, 147 soldiers had been killed in the fighting and 360 wounded.

The U.N. report said armed militias roaming the areas under rebel control have created a "reign of fear," killing and torturing civilians who show support for Kiev. The fighters include many who have come in from Russia, including Chechnya and other republics of the North Caucasus, it said.

Mr. Poroshenko is scheduled to meet with business and other leaders from the restive east Thursday in Kiev, local news agencies reported, without providing details on who would be invited. The government has said it won't negotiate with separatist fighters or their leaders.

On Wednesday, he began assembling a pro-Western team, asking parliament to replace the country's central-bank chairman with a veteran investment banker, Valeria Gontareva, and to appoint Ukraine's current ambassador to Germany, Pavlo Klimkin, as the new foreign minister.
He also asked parliament to approve the appointment of Deputy Prime Minister Vitaliy Yarema to the post of general prosecutor.
As the possibility of a peace deal took form, Mr. Poroshenko said government forces were continuing in their effort to regain control of the border and encircle the rebel stronghold of Slovyansk.

"We are carrying out decisive steps and successful operations to renew [control] of the state border," he said. "We are doing everything to surround Slovyansk. We are advancing, the circle is tightening to eliminate the insurgents."
But a State Border Service official said there were still long stretches of the border that remained in rebel hands.

A spokeswoman for Ukraine's Interior Ministry in Luhansk region said that four people were killed and 27 wounded on Tuesday in heavy fighting on the outskirts of the regional capital. Among the dead were Russian state television reporters Igor Kornelyuk and Anton Voloshin.
Ukraine's prime minister repeated a claim that Russian saboteurs were responsible for an explosion along a key gas transit pipeline the day before.

"We predicted several weeks ago that acts of sabotage would be staged to undermine Ukraine's reputation as a reliable transit country," Arseniy Yatsenyuk was quoted as saying by the Interfax news agency.
Vitaly Markelov, the deputy head of Russia's state-run gas company OAO Gazprom, blamed poor maintenance of the pipeline in Ukraine.
article-body.tagline: Peter Kenny in Geneva contributed to this article.
article-body.p: Write to James Marson at james.marson@wsj.com and Lukas I. Alpert at lukas.alpert@wsj.com
